title: Review Distilled Q&As from STITCH Paper
context: Reviewing extracted knowledge for memory project integration

questions.text:
Q: What is STITCH?
A: STITCH (Structured Intent Tracking in Contextual History) is an agentic memory system that indexes each trajectory step with a structured retrieval cue called contextual intent.
questions.reason: Directly relevant to plan_state retrieval design

questions.text:
Q: What is CAME-Bench?
A: The Context-aware Agent Memory Evaluation Benchmark, a synthetic dataset designed to evaluate agentic memory in continuous, goal-oriented trajectories.

Q: What dataset sizes were used in CAME-Bench evaluation?
A: 100 entities for the small partition and 200 for the large partition.

Q: How does STITCH improve over baselines?
A: STITCH outperforms the strongest baseline by 35.6%, with the largest gains as trajectory length increases.
questions.reason: Key result demonstrating value of intent-aware retrieval

questions.text:
Q: What are the three components of contextual intent?
A: (1) the current latent goal defining a thematic segment, (2) the action type, and (3) the salient entity types anchoring which attributes matter.
questions.reason: Core concept for implementing plan_state schema
